head.title: Mom Goes Shopping for a Shiny New Gun

hedline.hl1: Mom Goes Shopping for a Shiny New Gun

block.p: ''Wife, Mom, Bounty Hunter,'' which makes its debut on the WE network tonight, is the third reality show about bounty hunters in recent years. (''Human Bonds'' had a 10-episode run on HBO in 2004, and ''Dog the Bounty Hunter'' is going strong on A&E.) If this keeps up, there may be more TV bounty hunters than criminals.

Maybe these breathless portrayals of strapping, tough-talking law enforcers are the new westerns. More likely, they're the new sitcoms. ''Wife'' doesn't have a laugh track, but it offers a motley crew of characters making fools of themselves without realizing it. Sometimes the situations are farcical; many end with hugging and learning.
The WE’s reality show, which features a motherly bounty hunter who apprehends scofflaws by day and takes care of her family by night, is short on action and interesting characters.

''Wife, Mom, Bounty Hunter,'' which makes its debut on the WE network tonight, is the third reality show about bounty hunters in recent years. (''Human Bonds'' had a 10-episode run on HBO in 2004, and ''Dog the Bounty Hunter'' is going strong on A&E.) If this keeps up, there may be more TV bounty hunters than criminals.

Maybe these breathless portrayals of strapping, tough-talking law enforcers are the new westerns. More likely, they're the new sitcoms. ''Wife'' doesn't have a laugh track, but it offers a motley crew of characters making fools of themselves without realizing it. Sometimes the situations are farcical; many end with hugging and learning.
Even when things get gritty, ''Wife'' has the potential for uplift. No matter how bad your day was, it probably didn't involve handcuffs and a pat-down. Some TV we watch to feel good about ourselves.

Sandra Scott, a former professional wrestler, is a suburban Phoenix bounty hunter who apprehends scofflaws by day and takes care of her family by night. She mothers everybody. A teenage fugitive gets a hamburger and a lecture on the way to jail, and Sandra's husband, Ron, a video game fanatic 11 years her junior, gets a lesson on ordering steak in a restaurant. The children are 15-year-old Sabree, preoccupied with cheerleading and hair care, and 6-year-old Ever-Skye, who splits her time between the Scotts' tract house and her father's home in California.

If the Scotts were richer, they could be in the cast of ''The Real Housewives of Orange County,'' with whom they share a tank-top wardrobe and flashy, characterless décor. Ms. Scott sees herself as a girl who likes to have fun. Early on, she and her fellow bounty hunter Theresa go shopping, and not for Capri pants.
''Some girls like shopping for clothes, some like shoes, and we like guns,'' she says, trying out a sporty revolver. In her hands it seems as innocuous as a pair of espadrilles.

Ms. Scott's days, at least in the first three episodes, are not exactly pulse-pounding. Among the bail violators she brings to justice -- or at least to jail -- are a frightened young girl and an apparent methamphetamine addict who tells jokes while handcuffed in the back of a car.
There's a moment of tension when Ms. Scott and her team enter a house, guns at the ready, to flush out a fugitive. He turns out to be seriously ill.

In an era of shocking gun violence, it seems wrong to criticize a television series for not being brutal enough. And the producers removed a scene showing Ms. Scott and her partners at a firing range in deference to this week's events in Blacksburg, Va. Still, ''Wife'' could use a little more action.

The real energy here is psychological. Everybody has a story or, at least, an excuse. The meth addict, handcuffed and flanked by Ms. Scott's behemoth partners, offers hers: ''My intentions are good, but I have stress disorder.''
A few minutes later Ms. Scott catches her husband without his wedding ring. His excuse: ''I work with nine-volt batteries.''
Huh? There are clear fault lines in the Scott household. Unless the criminals get more interesting, expect the family to erupt, and to be fully exploited.
Wife, Mom, Bounty Hunter WE, tonight at 9, Eastern and Pacific times; 8, Central time.
Produced by World of Wonder; Randy Barbato and Fenton Bailey, executive producers; Kevin Leadingham, supervising producer.
